reference: Volume Three, Issue Thirty-Six, File 5 of 11
title: Elite Access! A Tutorial On Being An Elite Hacker
date: September 25, 1986, Revised May 2, 1988, Revised Again August 20, 1991
historical_context: This article reflects the hacker culture of the mid-1980s, a time when bulletin board systems (BBS) were the primary means of communication and information sharing among hackers and phreakers. It provides insight into the mindset and social dynamics of the underground community.
target_audience: Aspiring hackers, BBS users, security professionals, and those interested in hacker culture history.
short_summary: This article serves as a tongue-in-cheek tutorial for aspiring elite hackers, detailing how to gain access to elite BBS systems. It discusses the social dynamics of the underground community, the role of Sysops, and strategies for validation and impersonation.
summary:
In 'Elite Access!', Dead Lord and Lord Digital provide a satirical yet informative guide for those looking to infiltrate elite hacker BBS systems. The authors describe the self-perceived superiority of elite hackers and the peculiar social hierarchy that exists within the underground community. They emphasize that being 'elite' often has less to do with actual hacking skills and more with the ability to navigate social interactions and present oneself convincingly to Sysops, the gatekeepers of these boards. The article outlines various tactics for gaining access, including crafting impressive feedback messages and utilizing fake identities to bypass voice validation requirements. 

The authors also delve into the psychology of Sysops, portraying them as egotistical figures who crave validation from their users. They provide humorous yet practical advice on how to manipulate Sysops into granting access, including the importance of appearing knowledgeable and connected within the community. The article concludes with a cautionary note about the risks of getting caught, underscoring the need for careful management of one's online persona. Overall, 'Elite Access!' captures the essence of hacker culture during its formative years, blending humor with practical insights into the underground world of hacking.
